the level design means that different levels require totally different strategies. One level may require you to build the tallest tower you can while another may require you to build a small mobile structure while avoiding saws or fire. Another may have you selectively sacrifice some of your goo. This combination of different elements and challenges means that the game never once gets stale or boring. Each level feels wholly unique and the steady progression of difficulty and complexity is finely tuned. I found myself playing World of Goo for much longer sessions than I set out to. One important aspect of this is "time bugs" which allow you to go back in time by just a single goo ball placement. The only negative I can really mention is that the game can feel a bit dated, at this point. I loaded it up this year and all the charm is still there, but the graphics and controls have not aged all that well. Regardless, its a classic.

reviewText:
Where to start with this...
I originally played this on a Powermac G5 when it first came out around the end of 2008, I remember that I originally got it sometime around the 2008 election. My attention was focused on this game the whole time.

It's one of those games where it seems extremely simple at first, but then the complexities and depth of it gradually shine through. The puzzles are neat, and I never had to use any skips until the last part (and I normally sucka t puzzles) but they don't feel easy, they feel satisfying regardless.

The visuals are nice, and they're crisp and good looking, and most importantly they do NOT resort to trying to look like pixel art. However, the game does run at a low resolution and there is no way to change it.

The soundtrack... Well, let's just say it's one of the best soundtracks in an Indie game ever produced. It is well performed, it is entirely originally composed, and it doesn't resort to sounding like chiptune or 16-bit stuff to try and manipulate nostalgic nerves. One of the best parts of the game for certain, and even better is that all of the soundtrack (the full versions, not the shortened versions in the game) can be found right on Youtube. Very memorable soundtrack, I can say that about very very few games.

Buy it? YES! It's on sale frequently anyways.

World of Goo is a short and sweet little game that is hard to dislike.

The well balanced physics-based puzzles are thoughtful and intuitive, making you feel rather smart for solving them without ever getting too frustrating or difficult.

The level design complements the art design and always varies, so while the basic mechanics remain the same, World of Goo manages to feel extremely fresh thoughout, never retreading old ground.

The mouse controls can be finnicky sometimes, but this will only frustrate the hardcore players attempting to 100% the achievements by completing all of the OCD variants.

That's my one major complaint with the game: a casual run-through is kept rather easy, while the OCD objectives (time limits, number of goo balls, number of moves, etc.) are very tough, and can be screwed up with tiny control mistakes or physics misjudgements. reviewText:
World of Goo is a good, classic, indie game toplay when your bored. The only dissatisfaction about this game is that there is no story, each chapter in this game gives a weird and little about the story. You go from watching ballons carry goo to the clouds, watch the world turn 3D (it doesnt really turn 3D its still 2D) and the world literally covered in the end with goo.
World of Goo is a puzzle game which you must use a certain amount of goo given to you. However, not every goo is the same for example, green goo allows you to take it out again and put it somewhere else compared to black goo which is stuck forever.
If your the type of person to get 100% on this game well good luck cause every level has an extremly hard OCD to beat. It might either be to use a certain amount of goo, how many moves you must do or the most terrifying thing in any video game, TIME TRIALS. There is an interesting thing in the game where if you make a wrong move, a time bug will appear on your screen, in my opinion is perfect for any new gamers however they wont appear until you 1st stick goo together. 1 last thing is if you cant beat a level, you can literally skip it but theres 2 ways if you wanna get it back, beat the level that you skipped or beat the chapter to get 3 skip buttons.
I give this game 7/10 because the story isnt good but the gameplay is great yet hard. I recommend this game to hardcore gamers. This game is not meant for new gamers.

reviewText:
___/World Of Goo\___
Drag and drop a variety of squeaking, sticky goo-balls to fabricate structures than can be complex, magnificent or grotesque to get your goo-balls across endless chasms, spiky sawblades and slimy pools and into the end-point of each level, a collection tube that satisfyingly hoovers up your goo-balls and spits out your score based on the volume of adorable slimy spheres you have saved.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
>Well-crafted challenges, many unique mechanics are thrown at you in the latter stages. Doesn't get frustating.

>Runs at a low resolution, doesn't look crisp or sharp. The aesthetic and design is eccentric and definitely unique.

>Music sets the mood very well and provides helpful cues. Every little goo-ball makes a distinct sound that makes them lovable personalities that you'll love to watch bouncing around.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

You will definitely get a few solid hours of excellent puzzle gameplay. The game can suck you in for hours, but doesn't take very long to complete.

reviewText:
It's a fun game. It's got a lot of puzzle variety and a pretty good amount of content. But it's so bare bones in certain areas that I was absolutely convinced it was a poorly done mobile port until somebody corrected me.

What am I talking about? Dispite being a PC game first, it has no options menu of any kind, you can't correct the resolution, change the graphics (though I doubt you would need to) or even do something as simple as change the game volume. Distinguishing between the balls must be hell if you're colorblind, a menu option for that would have been really helpful for a lot of people. It does not lock the mouse to one screen if you have multiple monitors, but still requires that you move your mouse to the edge of the screen in order to pan the camera. It has no keyboard controls, even though it could have direly used some, such as the ablity to pan the camera with the arrow keys which would have delt with the mouse not locking issue, and a key for undo which would remove the need to click those stupid bugs (or more often, accidentally click one when you're trying to do a quick action).

Did I like it? I kept playing through the problems and beat it, so yeah I must have liked it dispite its problems. At the same time, would I recommend it? no, especially not at the normal $10 price tag. I found the missing features made it feel very unpolished and at the price point there are a lot of better games. Maybe on sale I'd recommend it, but that isn't an option.

reviewText: This game is an example of very interesting concepts and very fascinating (and disturbing) art and story.  Unfortunately, it suffers from a difficulty curve based only on how time consuming and frustrating certain levels are.  Most of the challenges rely on either counter-intuitive presentation (e.g. requiring the player to fling goo balls into an area that claims to be dangerous but isn't) or making the player guess what the physics will decide to do next.  The interface is mostly just dragging goo balls where you want them, but many of the levels require dragging specific goo balls quickly, which is often impossible to do because of the game not selecting the right one if there's any overlap.  This issue is then made worse by only certain goo balls being removable after placing them (which the player has to figure out themselves) as well as by the only way of reversing a move being to click on the little bugs that pop up for no explained or intuitive reason twice.  Not once, twice.  If you only click on one reversal bug, the game almost always reverts back to the most inconvenient possible situation.\n\nThe two biggest things I took away from this game was a deep sense of boredom and the feeling that the makers don't understand how an object's center of gravity works.  Even the constantly moving goo balls do not explain those bizarre weight mechanics work

Simple game with great visuals, a fun soundtrack, and a solid premise. However, I do not recommend this game because of the physics. It is a physics puzzle game, but with zero control over what the free gooballs do and with unpredictable goo placement, it is needlessly difficult to build a cohesive tower without it toppling over. The puzzle should be in deciphering how to build a structure to get to the end pipe, not endlessly working the goos over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over because you can't get them to drop where you need them. Example: the Tower of Goo level should be a fun introduction on how to build tall towers; the solution is extremely obvious. Instead, you need to spend all your time retrying because the goos all run up one side of the tower and pull it down, or you can't get the goo to span the right previously placed gooballs. If I know where to put it to add integrity, and I simply can't because the game won't let me, I'm not solving a puzzle I'm rolling the dice. Even following a freaking youtube tutorial where someone beat the level, I couldn't replicate the solution. Does that sound like a puzzle to anyone else?

I'm no stranger to difficult games, but at least with many of those you know what you're doing wrong. This isn't intellectually stimulating or challenging, it's just tedious.

World of Goo is a physics based puzzle game, through the game you use different kind of goo balls each having different properties to construct an structure to reach wherever you want to go at.
Green goo balls can be de-attached after attaching them at will, red ones can be turn into ballons to avoid the structure or bridge since most of the time you'll be making a bridge to fall down, black one is the common one used to create the bridges, and more.
Each level comes with a special challenge to earn a OCD flag requiring skill and patience to get them all, as you complete levels you'll also can accumulate goos in your factory to make tall towers and compete around the world.
Unless you're a puzzle fan you'll probably never finish the game, and even if you are full price is not recommended.

This is a game that filled me with delight!  I found it interesting and absorbing, and I felt like I was playing with the same enthusiastic spirit I had as a child with blocks.

I delayed playing this for a long time.  I first picked it up in a Humble Bundle, messed with it  through the first chapter a bit and put it down for nearly two years.  Now for me, that's actually a pretty quick turn around on completing a game.  As is testament on my Backloggery, I still have Nintendo games that I've had since childhood that need beating.

As we were heading into the Holiday seasons, work is slowing down so I browsed my Steam list and decided on Goo.  No solid reason really, perhaps I was thinking back to the quirky and pleasant music, the sharp graphics, or interesting physics engine.  Perhaps it just because my work computer could handle it.  Whatever the reason,  I actually stuck it out and finished the game.

The game is not perfect by any means, I wouldn't even put it on a top ten list, but it is fun enough to enjoy as a casual title.  The most frustrating thing is picking up the wrong goo, or misplacing a goo when time is of the essence or you're looking to complete an OCD.  Very Frustrating.

The story is on the light side and trying to describe it might be futile, but it did involve Goo genocie (goonocide?) and a big evil corporation.   The ending where they find another planet with Goo's was suppose to be part of extra levels that were going to be released in the European version, but was canned since the developer felt it would of been too rushed.

Overall, worth the play.  God speed to any accomplishing the OCDs.

World of Goo! I highly doubt this review will be of any use to anyone, since the metascore and price of the game make it very hard to not give it a try. I got it on sale, $2.50. I'll start by letting you know that I blindly purchased this game with my only knowledge of it being the image, the name, the price, and the fact that way too many of my steam friends already owned it, so you, by reading a review of it, are already having a different experience than I am.

There are blobs of goo that have little funny faces and attributes based on their color and shape. There are basic black goos for most of the game that follow a satirical, unnecessary, but amazingly additive storyline. The game is brilliantly hilarious in a very, very subtle way that you will never follow if you take it too seriously or never read any of the wooden signs.

Gameplay! The actual gameplay is awesome, which feels like an awkward word for a game where you stack goos to make towers and bridges, but I seriously don't want to downplay how much I enjoyed playing this game. I played through even when it got exhaustively difficult, I still had some incentive to push through, and it was all worth it in the end. Extraordinarily entertaining, even at the end with those devilish red fiends. Really the artwork and the satire are what make me want to replay it.

If you've somehow avoided this game until now, find a way to play it.

Overall: 9.8/10 (There was like one level that I wish I could have skipped because it was challenging but boring.)

World of Goo is deceptive in how simple and casual it is in the beginning. Using sticky balls of goo, and later other materials, you will build bridges, towers, and other structures in order to complete each level.

What the game does best, however, is consistent innovation in both puzzles and atmosphere. The world is trapped somewhere between cartoonish, dark absurdism and a very light, humorous satire. You will be using goo to aid in a product launch, to judge in a beauty contest, and to destroy the Internet (it makes sense in context). As simple as the story is, it makes the most of the small parts it has.

Gameplay wise, World of Goo is difficult, but never unfair. A few of the later levels took half an hour or more of trial and error, but almost always this was due to ignoring a vital detail, taking too many risks, or simply failing to build a stable structure. Completing a mission, however, never fails to bring a sense of accomplishment, and often zooms out to see the proud structure now standing (or, humorously, the structure collapsing right after the level is complete).

I don't play a lot of puzzle games. Often times I become too frustrated to really enjoy myself. World of Goo, however, was too appealing for me to give up on, even as the later levels did their best to send my balloon-supported bridge into the bottomless pit after five minutes of making it PERFECT.

World of Goo is a pretty awesome game. It offers fun puzzles that aren't difficult to learn, but are incredibly difficult to master. I've been working at this game for quite some time; it got a lot easier once I realised that there were video walkthroughs for each level online (duh). But my favorite part, by far, is the music. Simply put, the soundtrack for this game, a one-off by 2D Boy made years ago doesn't haven any reason it should be good. But it IS. I only wish Steam would release it as a DLC so I could download it!

I do have some gripes; the puzzles can get a little repetitive, and I often found I was making the same basic structures over and over again with just a few added new flairs. By the end of the game, most of the puzzles were transparent, though the developers did do a good job of making the final puzzles of each section a little more challenging. Also, I found the resolution to be quite bothersome; the game is locked to full screen at, like, 800x600 resolution. On my 1080p monitor, that looked terrible. Yes, I'm aware you can change it by editing the config document, but my point is that there wasn't any built-in graphics interface. Oh well.

Overall, I think I can recommend this game. Didn't encounter any bugs over the almost fifteen hours it took for me to beat it. Nice, tidy programming. Very accessible, and challenging for those that want to collect the achievements -- but not TOO challenging. It's a solid buy, especially if you can pick it up on sale.

If you're looking for a puzzle game that packs both charm and challenge, then you've come to the right place. World of Goo is almost instantly addictive for players of all skill levels, with simple controls and play mechanics that are easily grasped.

Click and drag the adorable goo balls into position to construct towers, bridges, and other structures to reach your goal. You only have a limited number of goo balls, and since some of them need to exit the level safely, you'll have to avoid hasty decisions and start planning ahead. You must carefully consider where to place the next goo ball--and (when later goo balls with different abilities are introduced) WHICH goo ball to place. It may take a few tries (and retries...and maybe even MORE retries), but you'll feel a sense of accomplishment once you've nailed the goal. Even after you've beaten the level, you can replay it again later to see if you can figure out method of achieving the goal with less moves and faster times (the OCD" goals in the menu beckon you to try this).

The art style is clean and colorful. All of the characters and interactive elements are distinctive on the screen

Yeah, so this game is based around playing with sticky, gooey black balls. Sound fun? Well it is. Actually, this is one of the most addictive games I've ever had the priviledge of playing. For many reasons. First, the animation is pretty laid back. It is a game that definitely does not take itself too seriously. Second, the soundtrack is really good. And not just the music, which has a whole Kayamari feel to it, but the popping sounds that the goo balls make when you pull them apart, and the little 'yippee' they shout when you do something with them. Yes, these little goo balls are actually pretty cute.\n\nI highly recommend this game. Not only is it a great game but it is Linux compatible, which is where the future of gaming is, but I expect the studio is going to come out with some other awesome titles in the future.
